        Acid catalysis and the mechanism of decomposition of bis-p-phenylacetyl peroxide
        Bartlett, Paul D.; Leffler, John E.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1950), 72 (), 3030-5CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        cf. C.A. 44, 5803h. (PhCH2CO)2O2 (I) like Bz2O2 decomp. with mixed 1st-order and 3/2-order kinetics. It is an inefficient initiator of the polymerization of PhCH:CH2 at 0Â°, at which temp. I decomp. slightly faster than Bz2O2 does at 70Â°. Despite evidence that free radicals are involved in the decompn., this reaction is subject to general acid catalysis, the efficiency of an acid catalyst being parallel to its acid strength. It is concluded that I can decomp., according to the conditions, by both free-radical and ionic mechanisms and that a C.sbd.C bond as well as an O.sbd.O bond must be broken in the rate-detg. step. The products of decompn. of I in PhMe are: (PhCH2)2 47, PhCH2CH2OH (II) 31, and PhCH2CO2CH2Ph (III) 22%; in the presence of O the products are: II 15, III 33, and BzH 53%; in CCl4 there resulted (PhCH2)2 12, II 1, and III 24%; in the presence of iodine (PhCH2)2 23, III 5.7, and PhCH2I 3.8%. 2,1,4-HOC10H5O2 and I give 17% of the 3-benzyl deriv., m. 177-8.6Â°. The rate of decompn. of I is a linear function of the concn. of PhCH2CO2H. The catalytic consts. for the decompn. of I by acids in PhMe at 18Â° are (1./mol.-sec. Ã 104): Me3CCO2H 2.1, BzOH 3.0, PhCH2CO2H 4.0 (6 at 0Â°), ClCH2CO2H 38, Cl2CHCO2H 89, Cl3CCO2H 178. The rate of decompn. of Bz2O2 in C6H6 at 70Â° without acid and in the presence of AcOH, Cl2CHCO2H, and Cl3CCO2H increased perceptibly in that order but 0.3 M Cl3CCO2H increased the rate of decompn. less than 50% over the rate in pure C6H6, whereas with I the increase would have been about 120-fold. In AcOH 0.179 M H2SO4 increased the rate of decompn. of Bz2O2 only about 25% but lowered the apparent order of the reaction markedly.

        Hey, D. H.; Walker, E. W.

        cf. C.A. 38, 74.1. Î¿-O2NC6H4COCl (100 g.) in 100 cc. CHCl3, shaken at 2Â° with 200 cc. 20-vol. IV and 100 cc. C6H6, refluxed 48 h., give 3.8 g. 4,2-O2N(MeO2C)C6H3CO2H and 2.7 g. Me 4-nitro-2-biphenylcarboxylate (V), m. 70Â°. The mother liquor of IV, dild. with H2O, gives 12.5 g. of bis(5-nitro-2-carbomethoxybenzoyl) peroxide contg. some IV, m. 110Â°; boiling with C6H6 gives a mixt. of V and its 5-NO2 isomer; hydrolysis and ring closure give a mixt. of 2- and 3-nitrofluorenone. Bz2O2 (60 g.), added in small quantities to C5H5N at 100Â°, the C5H5N removed, and the residue refluxed 5 h. with 250 cc. 1:1 HCl, gives 35% of a mixt. of 2-, 3-, and 4-phenylpyridines. I and C5H5N give 87% Î¿-O2NC6H4CO2H but no nitrophenylpyridines; similar results were obtained with the m- and p-isomers of I. (p-ClC6H4CO)2O2 and (p-MeOC6H4CO)2O2 give 27% of the 2- and 4-(p-chlorophenyl)- and 2- and 4-(p-methoxyphenyl)pyridines. (1-C10H7CO)2O2 gives a small yield of 1-naphthylpyridine (picrate, pale yellow, m. 196Â°); (2-C10H7CO)2O2 gives a mixt. of the 3 isomeric 2-naphthylpyridines. II gives a mixt. of 2 isomeric Me Î¿-pyridylbenzoates whose picrates, orange-yellow, m. 243Â°, and yellow, m. 196Â°. (PhCH:CHCO)2O2 gives a small yield of 2-stilbazole. Bz2O2 and quinoline at 105Â° give a mixt. of phenylquinolines of which the 4- and 5-isomers were isolated pure. Picrates were prepd. of the following isomers: 6, yellow, m. 205Â°; 8, yellow, m. 200Â°; 7, yellow, m. 210Â°. (m-O2NC6H4CO)2O2 and BzOH, heated 1 h. at 150Â°, give 3'-nitro-4-biphenylcarboxylic acid, yellow, m. 301Â°, and the isomeric 3-carboxylic acid, m. 262Â°. Bz2O2 and Me2CHCH2CMe3 give C6H6, Ph2, BzOH, and 4-PhC6H4CO2H. The reactions of the peroxides conform to the free-radical mechanism proposed earlier (C.A. 29, 1410.2).

        Beckwith, A. L. J.; Cross, R. T.; Gream, G. E. Aust. J. Chem 1974, 27, 1673â 1692,  DOI: 10.1071/CH9741673
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        28
        Mechanism of lead tetraacetate decarboxylation. I. Tertiary carboxylic acids
        Beckwith, A. L. J.; Cross, R. T.; Gream, G. E.
        Australian Journal of Chemistry (1974), 27 (8), 1673-92CODEN: AJCHAS; ISSN:0004-9425.
        The reactions of cis- and trans-decalin-9-carboxylic acid, 2,2,3-trimethylbutanoic acid, and adamantane-1-carboxylic acid with Pb(OAc)4 in benzene and, in some cases, HOAc were studied. In each case the nature and distribution of the products is consistent with the hypothesis that the reaction mechanism involvesthe initial generation of tertiary radicals which are subsequentlyconverted to the related cations either by one-electron oxidn. byPb species, or via organolead intermediates which undergo heterolysis. The change in product distribution which occurs when the reactions are conducted in the presence of Cu salts indicates that tertiary radicals react rapidly with cupric species to afford organocopper intermediates from which olefins are derived by a cis-elimination process, and acetates by SNi or heterolytic mechanisms.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE2cXltVCnt7w%253D&md5=a5223aa4656c542b63453d6cc5ab014d

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        29
        Palladium-Catalyzed Decarboxylative Arylation of C-H Bonds by Aryl Acylperoxides
        Yu, Wing-Yiu; Sit, Wing Nga; Zhou, Zhongyuan; Chan, Albert S.-C.
        Organic Letters (2009), 11 (15), 3174-3177CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7060. (American Chemical Society)
        A Pd(OAc)2-catalyzed protocol for decarboxylative arylation of arom. C-H bond was developed using aryl acylperoxides as inexpensive aryl sources. Substrates contg. pyridyl, oxime, and oxazoline groups undergo effectively ortho-selective C-H arylation with excellent functional group tolerance. This arylation should begin by directing-group-assisted cyclopalladation, followed by the reaction of the palladacycle with aryl radicals generated in situ by thermal decompn. of the peroxides.

        30a
        Does reduction of organic peroxides by iodide ions really proceed via single electron transfer?
        Tokumaru, Katsumi
        Chemistry Letters (1992), (4), 523-6CODEN: CMLTAG; ISSN:0366-7022.
        The mechanism of reactions of diaroyl peroxides with I-, commonly utilized for their detn., is reexamd. in terms of single electron transfer (SET) theory; an SET mechanism was ruled out and an SN2 mechanism was postulated based on electron transfer theory .

        (b) Perrin, C. L.; Wang, J.; Szwarc, M. Two-Electron Transfer from Potassium Anion to Peroxides: Simultaneous or Stepwise?. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2000, 122, 4569â 4572,  DOI: 10.1021/ja9937369
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        30b
        Two-Electron Transfer from Potassium Anion to Peroxides: Simultaneous or Stepwise?
        Perrin, Charles L.; Wang, Jingtao; Szwarc, Michael
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2000), 122 (19), 4569-4572CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Reaction of the 2-electron donor K+Crown K- with phenylacetyl peroxide produces phenylacetic acid, toluene, bibenzyl, and benzyl phenylacetate. The formation of products derived from benzyl radical shows that some electron transfers must be stepwise and that the 2nd electron transfer, although very exothermic, is fast but not exceedingly so. This conclusion is supported by control expts. with Na naphthalenide, Na biphenylide, and NaI as reductants, and with benzoyl peroxide.

        30c
        Kinetics of reactions of acyl peroxides with alkali iodides. I. Reactions of aroyl peroxides with potassium iodide
        Tsuchihashi, G.; Miyajima, S.; Otsu, T.; Simamura, O.
        Tetrahedron (1965), 21 (5), 1039-48CODEN: TETRAB; ISSN:0040-4020.
        The kinetics of the reaction of aroyl peroxides with KI in 95.1% and abs. alc. at 11Â°, 20Â°, and 30Â° was investigated. Acid chlorides were prepd. by refluxing the corresponding acids with SOCl2 2-5 hrs. and fractionally distg. the product. The acid chlorides were converted to sym. substituted benzoyl peroxides, (RC6H4CO)2O2 (I) according to the method of Price and Krebs (Org. Syntheses Collective Vol. III, 649(1955)). The b.p. of the acid chlorides and decompn. point of the peroxides were tabulated. The reaction was carried out in abs. alc. in a thermostatically controlled colorimeter and the liberated iodine detd. photometrically as the I3- ion, using light with a characteristic transmission ranging from 320-400 mÎ¼. A soln. of I in 2 ml. alc. of known concn. and previously heated to the thermostat temp. was added by pipette to 23 ml. KI in alc. at known concn. and thermostat temp. in the colorimeter cuvette. The time at which 1 ml. I soln. was added was taken as the zero time of reaction. A typical run of Bz2O2 at 29.5Â° indicated pseudo 1st order kinetics and all other measurements were made according to Guggenheim's method (CA 21, 202), using the equation log (log It - log It+Ï) = A' - 0.4343 kt. It was demonstrated that the reaction is neither accelerated nor retarded by the light used for colorimetry. No induced decompn. of Bz2O2 was involved and a linear relation between k and the initial concn. of KI indicated that the rate of reaction is 1st order in KI. The kinetic measurements thus showed that the rates of the reactions in both abs. and 95.1% alc. were represented by the relation, rate = k2[Bz2O2][KI]. This rate law was readily derived by assuming the reaction sequence: Bz2O2 + KI â BzOK + BzOÂ· + IÂ·; BzOÂ· + KI â BzOK + IÂ·; 2IÂ· â I2, where the 1st reaction was regarded as the rate detg. process and the 2nd and 3rd as fast reactions. The energy of activation Ea and the frequency factor A were calcd. by using the Arrhenius equation by the method of least squares. The enthalpy of activation ÎH++ and the entropy of activation ÎS++ were calcd. by the usual method. The results were summarized. The rate of reaction in abs. alc. was twice as fast as in 95.1% alc. but the enthalpy of activation was higher in abs. alc. The decrease in rate in 95.1% alc. was mainly caused by decrease in the entropy of activation. The results of kinetic measurements with p- and m-substituted I were summarized and plots of log k2 vs. Î£Ï were shown. Evaluation by the method of least squares gave Ï = 0.756 Â± 0.034 in abs. alc. and Ï = 0.867 Â± 0.051 in 95.1% alc. The correlation coeffs. for Î£Ï and log k2 were 0.976 and 0.978 in abs. and 95.1% alc., resp. The values of k for p-MeOC6H4CO2O2CC6H4NO2-p are 0.663 and 0.423 in abs. and 95.1% alc., resp. Hammett plots showed that these values are valid when the sum of the substitution consts. for the p-MeO and p-NO2 group is used for Î£Ï. According to the mechanism given above, an electron-withdrawing substituent must increase the rate of the reaction and the pos. value obtained here was consistent with the mechanism. The rates of the 16 substituted I conformed to the Hammett law with neg. values. The mechanism of the reaction was discussed.

        30d
        Decomposition of benzoyl peroxide in the presence of iodine. I. Aromatic solvents
        Hammond, George S.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1950), 72 (), 3737-43CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        Iodine and Bz2O2 (0.78 mol. each) in 245 ml. C6H6, heated 33 hrs. at 79Â° (sealed tube), give 0.83 mol. BzOH, 0.032 mol. BzOPh, and 0.026 mol. PhI. In PhCl as solvent (48 hrs. at 79Â°), the products are: BzOH 0.107, p-BzOC6H4Cl 0.104, PhI 0.016, and p-IC6H4Cl 0.051 mol. The rate of Bz2O2 decompn. is const. over a range of iodine concns., but the relative rate of iodine uptake and the nature of the products depend upon the iodine concn. It is suggested that BzOI is formed and reacts rapidly with the solvent in nonradical reactions which are catalyzed by iodine. The products of the reaction indicate that the "cage effect" is unimportant in C6H6. A max. of 10% of the theory of CO2 is formed in the primary process.

        (e) Kochi, J. K.; Graybill, B. M.; Kurz, M. Reactions of Peroxides with Halide Salts. Electrophilic and Homolytic Halogenations. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1964, 86, 5257â 5264,  DOI: 10.1021/ja01077a043
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        30e
        Reactions of peroxides with halide salts. Electrophilic and homolytic halogenations
        Kochi, Jay K.; Graybill, Bruce M.; Kurz, Michael
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1964), 86 (23), 5257-64CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        The halogenation of aromatic substrates is accomplished with a homogeneous soln. of Bz2O2 and Li halide in HOAc or MeCN. LiBr reacts almost instantaneously with Bz2O2 and anisole to form bromoanisoles, in quant. yields, and at 65Â° LiCl forms chloroanisoles in similar high yields. The yields of halogenated products fall off with the reactivity of the aromatic component in a manner typical of electrophilic substitutions (anisole, 90-100%; PhMe, 82-95%; C6H6, 45-60%; PhCl, 20-30%; PhNO2, nil). In most cases benzoic acid can be isolated in quantitative yields (2 moles per mole of peroxide). The isomer distributions of the halogenated products are the same as those obtained from mol. halogen:anisole (Cl), 24% ortho, 76% para; (Br), 4% ortho, 96% para; PhMe (Cl), 61% ortho, 39% para; PhCl (Cl), 30% ortho, 70% para. The reaction of Bz2O2 and LiCl in the presence of less reactive aromatics such as C6H6 and PhNO2 also produces minor amts. of side product such as CO2 (1-4%), MeCl (â¼1%), C6H6 (<0.5%), PhCl (1-2%), Ph2 (<0.5%), and Cl. The decompn. of peroxides is markedly accelerated by halide ion. Thermolysis of Bz2O2 in 50% HOAc-PhMe proceeds with a half-life of approx. 20 hrs. at 65Â° and does not contribute significantly to the halide reaction, which is half over in less than an hr. The reaction is 1st order in Bz2O2 and 1st order in LiCl. The reaction with anisole is too rapid to follow at these temps. The rate of peroxide disappearance with chloride ion in HOAc-PhMe solns. is independent of cupric or ferric ion and only slightly affected by air. However, the products of the reaction are highly dependent on these additives. Significantly, in the absence of air, benzyl chloride (84-95%) is the major product and chlorotoluenes are only formed in minor amts. (2-6%). This reaction is unaffected by light. In strong contrast, the reaction in air or CuCl2 (catalytic amts.) forms very little benzyl chloride (3-8%) and chlorotoluenes (82-95%) are the major products. Reactions conducted in limited amts. of air give mixts. of benzyl chloride and chlorotoluenes in proportion to the O content. Together these products account for 85-95% of the material balance. Small amts. of BzH (4-6%) accompany the chlorotoluenes in air but not in the presence of CuCl2. The roles which BzHCl and mol. Cl play in these electrophilic and homolytic halogenations are discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®

        open URL

        (f) Bunce, N. J.; Tanner, D. D. Benzoyl Hypochlorite, an Intermediate in the Oxidation of Ionic Chlorides and Hydrogen Chloride by Benzoyl Peroxide. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1969, 91, 6096â 6102,  DOI: 10.1021/ja01050a028
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        30f
        Benzoyl hypochlorite, an intermediate in the oxidation of ionic chlorides and hydrogen chloride by benzoyl peroxide
        Bunce, N. J.; Tanner, Dennis D.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1969), 91 (22), 6096-102CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        The oxidn. of chloride ion by Bz2O2 yields BzOCl. Free-radical initiation causes the decompn. of this intermediate to PhCl and in this and other reactions, the intermediate shows the same chemistry as the intermediate in the Hunsdiecker reaction. In the presence of an alkane, the acyl hypochlorite functions as a free-radical chlorinating reagent. Investigation of the mechanism of this reaction suggests that atomic Cl is the chain-carrying species. When HCl is oxidized by Bz2O2 in the absence of an alkane, only traces of PhCl are produced. This is attributed to the rapid reaction of HCl with the acyl hypochlorite to give mol. Cl. In the presence of an added hydrocarbon, the Cl so formed yields alkyl chlorides by a free-radical process, the mechanism of which is complicated by the reversible reaction of the intermediate alkyl radicals with the HCl in the system.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaF1MXlt1eht7c%253D&md5=97fa7f9722bc001c0decd37220be68d3
        open URL

        Oxidative Dimerization of (Hetero)aromatic Amines Utilizing t-BuOI Leading to (Hetero)aromatic Azo Compounds: Scope and Mechanistic Studies
        Okumura, Sota; Lin, Chun-Hsuan; Takeda, Youhei; Minakata, Satoshi

        A straightforward synthetic method of both sym. and unsym. arom. azo compds. through an efficient and cross-selective oxidative dimerization of arom. amines using tert-Bu hypoiodite (t-BuOI) under metal-free and mild conditions has been developed. This method was also found applicable to the synthesis of heteroarom. azo compds. The spectroscopic study indicates the involvement of N,N-diiodoanilines in the oxidative reaction as the key intermediate.

        31c
        Photochemical transformations. XVII. Improved methods for the decarboxylation of acids
        Barton, D. H. R.; Faro, H. P.; Serebryakov, E. P.; Woolsey, N. F.
        Journal of the Chemical Society (1965), (April), 2438-44CODEN: JCSOA9; ISSN:0368-1769.
        cf. CA 62, 6429c. The photochemical decarboxylation of acyl hypoiodites has been investigated and shown to provide an efficient method for the preparation of the corresponding nor-iodides. Primary and secondary carboxylic acids are readily decarboxylated by using the lead tetraacetate-iodine reagent. The recently discovered tert-butyl hypoiodite has been shown to form acyl hypoiodites at room temperature. With this reagent primary, secondary, and tertiary acids, as well as the hitherto intractable glutaric and adipic acids, can be decarboxylated without difficulty.

        31f
        Base-Promoted Formal Arylation of Benzo[d]oxazoles with Acyl Chloride
        Wang, Lei; Ren, Xinyi; Yu, Jintao; Jiang, Yan; Cheng, Jiang
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (2013), 78 (23), 12076-12081CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
        A base-promoted formal arylation of benzo-[d]-oxazoles with acyl chloride was achieved in moderate to good yields. This reaction was triggered by the N-acylation of oxazole to form an iminium intermediate. Then, the addn. of H2O to the iminium formed the hemiacetal intermediate. After the sequential ring-opening, extrusion of CO, the ring closure, the dehydration delivered the formal arylation product. In comparison with the transition-metal-catalyzed methodol., it represents an alternative arylation method leading to 2-arylbenzoxazole.

        33a
        Preparation of 5-Substituted 1H-Tetrazoles from Nitriles in Water
        Demko, Zachary P.; Sharpless, K. Barry
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (2001), 66 (24), 7945-7950CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
        The addn. of sodium azide to nitriles to give 1H-tetrazoles is shown to proceed readily in water with zinc salts as catalysts. The scope of the reaction is quite broad; a variety of arom. nitriles, activated and unactivated alkyl nitriles, substituted vinyl nitriles, thiocyanates, and cyanamides have all been shown to be viable substrates for this reaction.

        (NH4)2Ce(NO3)6 as an inexpensive, eco-friendly, efficient catalyst for the synthesis of 5-substituted 1H-tetrazoles from nitriles
        Kumar, Satyanand; Dubey, Shristy; Saxena, Nisha; Awasthi, Satish Kumar
        Tetrahedron Letters (2014), 55 (44), 6034-6038CODEN: TELEAY; ISSN:0040-4039. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        Ceric ammonium nitrate (CAN) is found to be a suitable, inexpensive, and effective non-toxic catalyst for a smooth [3 + 2]-cycloaddn. of org. nitriles with NaN3 to afford 5-substituted 1H-tetrazoles in excellent yields. This method has short reaction time, easy work-up, and substantial and pure product formation.

        33d
        Safe and Efficient Tetrazole Synthesis in a Continuous-Flow Microreactor
        Palde, Prakash B.; Jamison, Timothy F.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2011), 50 (15), 3525-3528, S3525/1-S3525/53CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Reactions of nitriles and NaN3 were conducted in a continuous-flow microreactor. This method minimizes azide usage, minimizes HN3 generation, avoids HN3 accumulation and exposure, provides rate enhancement (safely), and suppresses nitrile hydration. Residual NaN3 is quenched in line with NaNO2. The reactions can be conducted at an elevated temp. (190 Â°C). This crit. reaction variable is in turn feasible only because the reaction format is flow, wherein there is no headspace in which HN3 could accumulate to an explosive level.

        Magnetically separable Fe3O4@chitin as an eco-friendly nanocatalyst with high efficiency for green synthesis of 5-substituted-1H-tetrazoles under solvent-free conditions
        Zarghani, Monireh; Akhlaghinia, Batool
        RSC Advances (2016), 6 (38), 31850-31860CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The present study describes an efficient, eco-friendly and simple method for the synthesis of 5-substituted-1H-tetrazoles catalyzed by magnetite-chitin (Fe3O4@chitin) as a green and recyclable catalyst.Fe3O4@chitin was initially prepd. using hydrothermal synthesis. Subsequently, the structure, morphol., and magnetic properties of the prepd. nanocatalyst were studied with some different spectroscopic, microscopic and thermogravimetric techniques such as FT-IR, XRD, SEM, TEM, VSM and TGA. Obtained results showed that Fe3O4@chitin nanoparticles exhibited uniform cubic shape and were well monodispersed. Also, magnetic measurement revealed that the synthesized nanocatalyst had superparamagnetic features. The application of this new nanocatalyst allows the synthesis of a variety of tetrazoles through the reaction of nitriles with 1-butyl-3-methylimidazolium azide ([bmim][N3]) under solvent-free conditions. This synthetic pathway is a green protocol offering significant advantages, such as excellent yield of products in short reaction times, mild reaction conditions, minimization of chem. waste, easy prepn. of the catalyst and its recyclability up to six cycles without any considerable loss of efficiency.

        (a) Becke, A. D. Density-Functional Thermochemistry. III. The Role of Exact Exchange. J. Chem. Phys. 1993, 98, 5648â 5652,  DOI: 10.1063/1.464913
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        34a
        Density-functional thermochemistry. III. The role of exact exchange
        Becke, Axel D.
        Journal of Chemical Physics (1993), 98 (7), 5648-52CODEN: JCPSA6; ISSN:0021-9606.
        Despite the remarkable thermochem. accuracy of Kohn-Sham d.-functional theories with gradient corrections for exchange-correlation, the author believes that further improvements are unlikely unless exact-exchange information is considered. Arguments to support this view are presented, and a semiempirical exchange-correlation functional (contg. local-spin-d., gradient, and exact-exchange terms) is tested for 56 atomization energies, 42 ionization potentials, 8 proton affinities, and 10 total at. energies of first- and second-row systems. This functional performs better than previous functionals with gradient corrections only, and fits expt. atomization energies with an impressively small av. abs. deviation of 2.4 kcal/mol.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®

        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        34b
        Gaussian basis sets for use in correlated molecular calculations. I. The atoms boron through neon and hydrogen
        Dunning, Thom H., Jr.
        Journal of Chemical Physics (1989), 90 (2), 1007-23CODEN: JCPSA6; ISSN:0021-9606.
        Guided by the calcns. on oxygen in the literature, basis sets for use in correlated at. and mol. calcns. were developed for all of the first row atoms from boron through neon, and for hydrogen. As in the oxygen atom calcns., the incremental energy lowerings, due to the addn. of correlating functions, fall into distinct groups. This leads to the concept of correlation-consistent basis sets, i.e., sets which include all functions in a given group as well as all functions in any higher groups. Correlation-consistent sets are given for all of the atoms considered. The most accurate sets detd. in this way, [5s4p3d2f1g], consistently yield 99% of the correlation energy obtained with the corresponding at.-natural-orbital sets, even though the latter contains 50% more primitive functions and twice as many primitive polarization functions. It is estd. that this set yields 94-97% of the total (HF + 1 + 2) correlation energy for the atoms neon through boron.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1MXksVGmtrk%253D&md5=c6cd67a3748dc61692a9cb622d2694a0
        open URL
        .
        (c) Woon, D. E.; Dunning, T. H., Jr. Gaussian Basis Sets for Use in Correlated Molecular Calculations. III. The Atoms Aluminum Through Argon. J. Chem. Phys. 1993, 98, 1358â 1371,  DOI: 10.1063/1.464303
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        34c
        Gaussian basis sets for use in correlated molecular calculations. III. The atoms aluminum through argon
        Woon, David E.; Dunning, Thom H., Jr.
        Journal of Chemical Physics (1993), 98 (2), 1358-71CODEN: JCPSA6; ISSN:0021-9606.
        Correlation consistent and augmented correlation consistent basis sets were detd. for the second row atoms. The methodol., originally developed for the first row atoms (T. H. D., Jr., 1989) is first applied to S. The exponents for the polarization functions (dfgh) are systematically optimized for a correlated wave function (HF+1+2). The (sp) correlation functions are taken from the appropriate HF primitive sets; these functions differ little from the optimum functions. Basis sets of double zeta [4s3p1d], triple zeta [5s4p2d1f], and quadruple zeta [6s5p3d2f1g] quality are defined. Each of these sets is then augmented with diffuse functions to better describe electron affinities and other mol. properties: s and p functions were obtained by optimization for the anion HF energy, while an addnl. polarization function for each symmetry present in the std. set was optimized for the anion HF+1+2 energy. The results for S are then used to assist in detg. double zeta, triple zeta, and quadruple zeta basis sets for the remainder of the second row of the p block.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3sXhtlans7Y%253D&md5=3f2e6860ac29511cb96da63f31bdc1ee

        (d) Halgren, T. A.; Lipscomb, W. N. The Synchronous-Transit Method for Determining Reaction Pathways and Locating Molecular Transition States. Chem. Phys. Lett. 1977, 49, 225â 232,  DOI: 10.1016/0009-2614(77)80574-5
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        34d
        The synchronous-transit method for determining reaction pathways and locating molecular transition states
        Halgren, Thomas A.; Lipscomb, William N.
        Chemical Physics Letters (1977), 49 (2), 225-32CODEN: CHPLBC; ISSN:0009-2614.
        In the synchronous-transit method, a model linear synchronous transit pathway is first constructed and is then refined by optimizing 1 or more intermediate structures subject to the constraint that the optimized structure retain the same relative position along the path orthogonal optimization. The method yields a series of energy ests. which progressively bound the energy of the transition state from above and from below. High computational efficiency is attainable, and sufficient flexibility is provided to deal with asynchronous processes. Comparisons are made to the alternative reaction-coordinate approach. The method is applied to a model 2-dimensional energy surface and to the allowed electrocyclic interconversions of the cyclopropyl and allyl cations and of cyclobutene and cis-butadiene.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE2sXlsFWmtLs%253D&md5=90c0d95b096220fddcc7eebc0639fdfd
        open URL
        .
        (e) Ayala, P. Y.; Schlegel, H. B. A Combined Method for Determining Reaction Paths, Minima and Transition State Geometries. J. Chem. Phys. 1997, 107, 375â 384,  DOI: 10.1063/1.474398
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        34e
        A combined method for determining reaction paths, minima, and transition state geometries
        Ayala, Philippe Y.; Schlegel, H. Bernhard
        Journal of Chemical Physics (1997), 107 (2), 375-384CODEN: JCPSA6; ISSN:0021-9606. (American Institute of Physics)
        Mapping out a reaction mechanism involves optimizing the reactants and products, finding the transition state and following the reaction path connecting them. Transition states can be difficult to locate and reaction paths can be expensive to follow. We describe an efficient algorithm for detg. the transition state, min. and reaction path in a single procedure. Starting with an approx. path represented by N points, the path is iteratively relaxed until one of the N points reached the transition state, the end points optimize to min. and the remaining points converged to a second order approxn. of the steepest descent path. The method appears to be more reliable than conventional transition state optimization algorithms, and requires only energies and gradients, but not second deriv. calcns. The procedure is illustrated by application to a no. of model reactions. In most cases, the reaction mechanism can be described well using 5 to 7 points to represent the transition state, the min. and the path. The computational cost of relaxing the path is less than or comparable to the cost of std. techniques for finding the transition state and the min., detg. the transition vector and following the reaction path on both sides of the transition state.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXksVeksrY%253D&md5=2ec17a4bf9a0f0f848e6fe0b844fe250
        open URL
        .
        (f) Barone, V. Vibrational Zero-point Energies and Thermodynamic Functions Beyond the Harmonic Approximation. J. Chem. Phys. 2004, 120, 3059â 3065,  DOI: 10.1063/1.1637580
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        34f
        Vibrational zero-point energies and thermodynamic functions beyond the harmonic approximation
        Barone, Vincenzo
        Journal of Chemical Physics (2004), 120 (7), 3059-3065CODEN: JCPSA6; ISSN:0021-9606. (American Institute of Physics)
        This paper compares harmonic and anharmonic zero-point energies and thermodn. functions for a no. of mols. of small and medium size. Anharmonic corrections cannot be neglected for quant. studies, but can be obtained quite effectively by a perturbative treatment including cubic force consts. to the second order and semidiagonal quartic consts. to the first order. Simple finite difference equations provide all the necessary terms by at most 6N-11 Hessian evaluations, where N is the no. of atoms in the system. Accurate values are obtained by this method using the Becke three parameter Lee-Yang-Parr functional, medium size basis sets, and, when needed, proper treatment of internal rotations. The whole model has been completely automated in the Gaussian package.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXht1Onsrk%253D&md5=4a1960dbe07372c83f955ccaad6864c2
        open URL

        35a
        A Three-Step Synthesis of Benzoyl Peroxide
        Her, Brenda; Jones, Alexandra; Wollack, James W.
        Journal of Chemical Education (2014), 91 (9), 1491-1494CODEN: JCEDA8; ISSN:0021-9584. (American Chemical Society and Division of Chemical Education, Inc.)
        Benzoyl peroxide is used as a bleaching agent for flour and whey processing, a polymn. initiator in the synthesis of plastics, and the active component of acne medication. Because of its simplicity and wide application, benzoyl peroxide is a target mol. of interest. It can be affordably synthesized in three steps from bromobenzene using procedures that can be performed in four, 4 h lab. periods. This process includes a Grignard reaction to turn bromobenzene into benzoic acid, nucleophilic acyl substitution to transform the resulting carboxylic acid into an acid chloride, and the addn. of H2O2/NaOH to the acid chloride to yield benzoyl peroxide. Most org. chem. students are familiar with these traditional reaction mechanisms because they are covered in introductory org. chem. courses. The starting materials for each reaction are com. available, and the products can be readily characterized using NMR spectroscopy, IR spectroscopy, and m.p.

        36a
        Sodium hydrogen exchanger inhibitory activity of benzotriazole derivatives
        Singh, Dhandeep; Silakari, Om
        European Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2017), 126 (), 183-189CODEN: EJMCA5; ISSN:0223-5234. (Elsevier Masson SAS)
        Series of benzotriazole derivs. I [R = Me, Et, benzoyl, sulfonyl, etc.] and II [R2 = Me, Et, heptyl, etc.] were synthesized and evaluated for their sodium hydrogen exchanger-1 inhibitory potential. All compds. I and II inhibited sodium hydrogen exchanger-1 in the in-vitro platelet swelling assay. This was perhaps the first report of NHE-1 inhibitory activity of benzotriazole. The 1-substituted benzotriazoles I [R = Me, Et, benzoyl, sulfonyl, etc.] were found to be more active than the 2-alkyl isomers II. The activity increased with increase in chain length of alkyl moiety. Potency increased from that of benzotriazole (IC50 = 192.68Î¼M) to compd. I [R = heptyl] (IC50 = 59.23Î¼M). Introduction of electroneg. oxygen atom further increased potency as shown by the compd. I [R = benzoyl] (IC50 = 51.57Î¼M) and I [R = sulfonyl] (IC50 = 50.89Î¼M; I [R = tosyl], IC50 = 49.95Î¼M).

        Regiospecific synthesis of N2-aryl 1,2,3-triazoles from 2,5-disubstituted tetrazoles via photochemically generated nitrile imine intermediates
        Stewart, Sam; Harris, Robert; Jamieson, Craig
        Synlett (2014), 25 (17), 2480-2484CODEN: SYNLES; ISSN:0936-5214. (Georg Thieme Verlag)
        The synthesis of N2-aryl 1,2,3-triazoles, e.g., 2-(4-aminophenyl)-4,5-diethyl-1,2,3-triazole, from 2,5-disubstituted tetrazoles, e.g., 2-(4-aminophenyl)-5-ethyl-1,2,3,4-tetrazole, was achieved under photochem. conditions. This simple and mild one-step reaction provides regiospecific access to 2,4,5-substituted 1,2,3-triazoles I (R1 = H, 4-Cl, 3-Cl, 4-OMe, R2 = H, 4-Me, 4-OMe, 3-OMe, 2-OMe, 4-NH2, 4-NHCOMe, 4-CO2Et) via a nitrile imine intermediate.         open URL
        .
        (b) Li, J.; Huang, L.; Xiao, X.; Chen, Y.; Wang, X.; Zhou, Z.; Zhang, C.; Zhang, Y. Photoclickable MicroRNA for the Intracellular Target Identification of MicroRNAs. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2016, 138, 15943â 15949,  DOI: 10.1021/jacs.6b08521
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        37b
        Photoclickable MicroRNA for the Intracellular Target Identification of MicroRNAs
        Li, Jinbo; Huang, Lei; Xiao, Xiao; Chen, Yingjie; Wang, Xingxing; Zhou, Zhengquan; Zhang, Chenyu; Zhang, Yan
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2016), 138 (49), 15943-15949CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are important gene regulators that bind with target genes and repress target gene expression at post-transcriptional level. The identification of target genes assocd. with miRNAs inside different cells is of major challenge in miRNA chem.-biol. due to lack of functional miRNAs bearing appropriate tags. Here we report photo-clickable miRNAs as appropriately pre-tagged miRNAs that keep the intracellular function of miRNAs and allow the addn. of mol. handles through photo-click reaction. The photo-clickable miRNAs upon transfection inside cells were able to form functional complexes with target genes and repress target gene expression. Target genes assocd. with the photo-clickable miRNA in the complex were then tagged with the mol. handle through photo-click reaction for pull-down and identification. Using photo-clickable miR-106a, miR-27 and miR-122, we firstly verified that their intracellular function was comparable to intact miRNAs, which showed obvious advantage over corresponding biotinylated miRNAs. After attaching the biotin handle to the assocd. complex contg. the photo-clickable miRNAs through the tetrazole-ene photo-click reaction, target genes previously bound with these miRNAs inside cells were successfully pulled town and analyzed. The application of this strategy was demonstrated by the identification of several new target genes of miR-122, followed by revealing a novel regulatory pathway in HepG2 cells with regard to the role of PEG10 in miR-122-promoted cell apoptosis.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhvFWgtb7O&md5=786f5485c051f3003a4a23f33d79808c
        open URL
        .
        (c) Shawali, A. S.; Fahmi, A. A.; Eweiss, N. F. Azo Coupling of Benzenesulfonylhydrazones of Heterocyclic Aldehydes. J. Heterocycl. Chem. 1979, 16, 123â 128,  DOI: 10.1002/jhet.5570160123
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        37c
        Azo coupling of benzenesulfonylhydrazones of heterocyclic aldehydes
        Shawali, A. S.; Fahmi, A. A.; Eweiss, N. F.
        Journal of Heterocyclic Chemistry (1979), 16 (1), 123-8CODEN: JHTCAD; ISSN:0022-152X.
        The reaction of RCH:NNHSO2Ph (R = Ph, 4-MeC6H4, 4-MeOC6H4, 4-ClC6H4, 4-BrC6H4, 4-O2NC6H4, 3-O2NC6H4, 4-HOC6H4, 4-Me2NC6H4, 2-furyl, 2-thienyl, 3-pyridyl, 4-pyridyl) with diazotized R1NH2 (R1 = Ph, 4-MeC6H4, 4-MeOC6H4, 4-ClC6H4, 4-O2NC6H4, 4-HO2CC6H4, 3-pyridyl) gave the tetrazoles I. The yield of I depended to some extent on the nature of R. The structures of I were established on the basis of their anal. and spectral data. A tentative explanation for their formation is proposed. The acid diassocn. consts. of I were also detd.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE1MXhs1yms7w%253D&md5=c49f6e7f5db5da0773fb9dac092f88a8
        open URL
        .
        (d) Ramanathan, M.; Wang, Y. H.; Liu, S.-T. One-Pot Reactions for Synthesis of 2,5-Substituted Tetrazoles from Aryldiazonium Salts and Amidines. Org. Lett. 2015, 17, 5886â 5889,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.orglett.5b03068
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        37d
        One-Pot Reactions for Synthesis of 2,5-Substituted Tetrazoles from Aryldiazonium Salts and Amidines
        Ramanathan, Mani; Wang, Yu-Hao; Liu, Shiuh-Tzung
        Organic Letters (2015), 17 (23), 5886-5889CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
        One-pot sequential reactions of aryldiazonium salts with amidines followed by the treatment with I2/KI under basic conditions provide 2,5-disubstituted tetrazoles in moderate to excellent yields. This one-pot synthesis has several advantages such as mild reaction conditions, short reaction time, convenient workup, and high yields, making this methodol. practical.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvFWgt7fN&md5=40d741ed04293444e0c44c5814ba86b8
        open URL
        .
        (e) Ito, S.; Tanaka, Y.; Kakehi, A. Synthesis of 2,5-Diaryltetrazoles from N-Phenylsulfonylbenzhydrazidoyl Chlorides and Arylhydrazines. Bull. Chem. Soc. Jpn 1976, 49, 762â 766,  DOI: 10.1246/bcsj.49.762
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        37e
        Synthesis of 2,5-diaryltetrazoles from N-phenylsulfonylbenzhydrazidoyl chlorides and arylhydrazines
        Ito, Suketaka; Tanaka, Yumo; Kakehi, Akikazu
        Bulletin of the Chemical Society of Japan (1976), 49 (3), 762-6CODEN: BCSJA8; ISSN:0009-2673.
        Thirty tetrazoles I (R = H, Me, Cl, MeO, cyano, O2N; R1 = H, Me, Br, NO2) were prepd. in 16-70% yields by condensing p-RC6H4CCl:NNHSO2Ph with H2NNHC6H4R1-p, presumably via concerted elimination of arenesulfinic acid from p-R1C6H4N:NC(C6H4R-p):NNHSO2Ph.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE28Xkt1Whsbk%253D&md5=267d08d87e6cc19603a670c5d44507ad
        open URL
      38. 38
        Li, Y.; Han, Y.; Xiong, H.; Zhu, N.; Qian, B.; Ye, C.; Kantchev, E. A. B.; Bao, H. Copper-Catalyzed Regioselective 1,2-Alkylesterification of Dienes to Allylic Esters. Org. Lett. 2016, 18, 392â 395,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.orglett.5b03399
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        38
        Copper-Catalyzed Regioselective 1,2-Alkylesterification of Dienes to Allylic Esters
        Li, Yougui; Han, Yulong; Xiong, Haigen; Zhu, Nengbo; Qian, Bo; Ye, Changqing; Kantchev, Eric Assen B.; Bao, Hongli
        Organic Letters (2016), 18 (3), 392-395CODEN: ORLEF7; ISSN:1523-7052. (American Chemical Society)
        Copper catalyzed 1,2-alkylesterification of 1,3-dienes with diacyl peroxides affords branched allylic esters in excellent regioselectivity, including products with a newly generated fully substituted carbon center. The only byproduct is CO2. The reaction proceeds by a radical mechanism as suggested by spin trap and crossover expts.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xhs1Orsr8%253D&md5=7a3f645d7c7a6dcfebce40da0df70e9c
        open URL
